newsitem.title: UK: Chronology of highlights in the LME copper saga.
newsitem.headline: Chronology of highlights in the LME copper saga.

text.p: Scandal in copper took a new turn on Tuesday with the Tokyo arrest of ex-Sumitomo Corp star trader Yasuo Hamanaka.
Here is a chronology of some key events surrounding copper trading on the London Metal Exchange (LME) since 1991.

NOVEMBER 1991 - The International Wrought Copper Council (IWCC) representing the industry asks the LME to investigate alleged distortions in the market. LME stocks were at seven-year highs of 315,000 tonnes. Yet prices were up.

US broker David Threlkeld asks LME to investigate a letter in which he said Hamanaka asked him to confirm fictitious trades. The LME informs the British regulatory Securities and Investments Board (SIB) and US authorities.
SEPTEMBER 1993 - Sumitomo denies manipulating copper by hoarding it. Hamanaka will contend that it needed large stocks to cover delivery commitments in Asia.
OCTOBER 1993 - LME broker Credit Lyonnais Rouse apologises to the exchange over any involvement in an alleged squeeze and pays 100,000 sterling ($125,000) towards exchange costs.
JANUARY 1994 - Chile Copper Corp (Codelco) announces losses on LME trading eventually fixed at around $170 million. Head dealer Juan Pablo Davila has since denied fraud.

JULY 1994 - LME asks members if they are having difficulties with payments from state firm China International Trust and Investment Corp. A CITIC unit has debts of $40 million with some 14 LME brokers. It says some trades were unauthorised.
MARCH 1995 - CITIC agrees a settlement with brokers.
APRIL 1995 - LME opens copper warehouses in the US. By December stocks in Long Beach will soar above 61,000 tonnes. Largely controlled by Sumitomo.
NOVEMBER 1995 - IWCC voices new concern about the market. LME Chief Executive David King seeks information on client positions and credit.
DECEMBER 1995 - US regulator the Commodity Futures Trading Commission (CFTC) contacts the British SIB. Codelco starts lawsuits against some brokers.
MARCH 1996 - US funds sell copper short. Price falls.
APRIL 1996 - Traders report rumours China seeks to buy copper. Price rises towards a 1996 peak at $2,715 early May as funds are squeezed on short positions.
MAY 17 1996 - Rumours circulate that Hamanaka has moved from his post. A rise in LME stocks despite talk of Chinese withdrawals of metal triggers a huge sell-off
JUNE 5 1996 - Sumitomo says this was the day when it found evidence of unauthorised trading.
JUNE 6 1996 - Copper crashes from $2,378 to $1,880 a tonne.
JUNE 11 1996 - New rumours that Hamanaka has resigned. Price falls $200. Sumitomo denies the rumour the next day.

JUNE 14 - Sumitomo reports losses of $1.8 billion on unauthorised copper trades. It sacks Hamanaka. Banks are soon asked to unwind a huge long position that Hamanaka built up. The UK Serious Fraud Office opens its own criminal inquiry to be followed in the US by a Grand Jury investigation. Prices drop.
JUNE 17 - Price as low as $1,800.
JUNE 19 - The UK SIB opens a top-to-bottom review of metals trading and inquiry into Sumitomo involvement of UK brokers.
AUGUST 11 - Hamanaka makes his first appearance since he was sacked to say he is well and living quietly in Tokyo.
SEPTEMBER 2 - Reports say that Japanese prosecutors will set up a task force to investigate Sumitomo losses.
SEPTEMBER 19 - Sumitomo says these are now put at $2.6 billion.Copper price barely reacts. Sumitomo also says it asks for criminal charges against Hamanaka.

OCTOBER 22 - Tokyo prosecutors arrest him on charge of falsifying documents. But Sumitomo says in a statement it has no evidence of market manipulation against foreign brokers. UK Serious Fraud Office says its inquiry will continue.
($1=.7986 Sterling)
